Package silhouette.shapes

The shapes package contains all of the classes for creating and displaying Silhouette shapes.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
DisplayManager The interface for all objects wishing to implement a DisplayManager for Silhouette objects.
SilContainer An interface for Silhouette objects that contain other Silhouette objects
SilShape The abstract ancestor for all Silhouette shapes.
 

Class Summary
AbstractSilShape The abstract ancestor for all Silhouette shapes.
ArrowLineShape A Arrowline that is drawn on the screen.
BagDisplay This is the default DisplayManager for all Silhouette containers.
BoxShape The base class for rectangular shapes, like roundtangles, ellipses, rectangles, composite objects and text objects.
CanvasShape CanvasShape is a Composite Shape that can display Silhouette shapes.
CircleShape A Ellipse that is drawn on the screen.
CompositeShape CompositeShape is the workhorse of the Silhouette system.
EditableTextShape Change Log: 10/1/00, Weizhong Ji: Created EditableTextShape 10/8/00, bvz: 1) Changed name of class from EditableText to EditableTextShape 2) Augmented the SilCaret class so that it contains all the state information required to perform a text edit 3) Created a static variable containing the text edit interactor so that there is only one interactor for the entire class rather than one interactor for each instance of the class.
EllipseShape A Ellipse that is drawn on the screen.
ImageShape A gif, jpeg, or bitmap image that is drawn on the screen.
LineShape A line that is drawn on the screen.
RectangleShape A rectangle that is drawn on the screen.
SilCanvas  
SilPanel SilPanel extends JPanel to let SilCanvas to be attached to, it itself should be added to componentPane.
TextShape TextShape is a non-editable line of text drawn on the screen.
 

Package silhouette.shapes Description

The shapes package contains all of the classes for creating and displaying Silhouette shapes.

The shapes package defines a number of primitive graphical shapes, a composite shape that can be used to assemble primitive shapes into more complex shapes, and a canvas shape that can be used to display the primitive and composite shapes. The Java2D graphics package also defines a number of primitive shapes. However, the shapes package provides a number of services not provided by the Java2D package:

  1. Automatic Redisplay: Whenever a Silhouette canvas's paint method is called, it automatically redraws all the Silhouette shapes and swing components that have been added to the canvas. The Java2D graphics model requires the programmer to manually erase and redraw all custom 2D shapes.

  2. Retained Object Model: Java2D provides a retained object model that keeps track of a shape's coordinates. Silhouette provides a beefed up retained object model that keeps track of a shape's other properties, such as its fill color, its line color, and whether or not it is visible. When a canvas's paint method is called, the canvas automatically sets the graphics context to an object's properties before drawing the object.

  3. Composite Shapes: Silhouette provides a grouping construct, called a composite shape, that allows primitive shapes to be assembled into more complex shapes. Instances of composite shapes can be created just like instances of primitive shapes. When an instance of a composite shape is created, the composite shape also creates instances of all the primitive shapes that comprise it. Composite shapes can also consist of other composite shapes, thus allowing a programmer to build up a library of shapes.

Silhouette differs from the Java2D graphics package in the way it displays objects on the screen. The Java2D graphics package requires the programmer to explicitly call draw commands to display shapes on the screen. In contrast, Silhouette requires the programmer to 1) create an instance of the shape to be drawn on the screen, 2) set the display properties of the shape using the created object's various set property methods, and 3) add the object to a Silhouette canvas. Adding the object to the Silhouette canvas is like adding a Swing component to a JComponent. It registers the shape with the canvas so that the canvas knows about it and can draw it when the canvas's paint method is called.

The set of shapes currently defined by the shapes package includes:

  1. CanvasShape: The object used to display Silhouette shapes.
  2. RectangleShape
  3. LineShape
  4. ArrowLineShape
  5. TextShape
  6. EditableTextShape
  7. EllipseShape
  8. CircleShape
  9. ImageShape: Uses Java's ImageIcon class to retrieve an image file and display it.

The shapes package also has a number of advanced features that can be used to extend the package.
